instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
I'm a little confused by this one. The only liquid damage is in the upper lefthand corner beside the backlight circuit. I have checked that area for shorts with no luck. I have the g3 hot rails, but no P5vS0 rail. And I think (I am new to this) the P5vS3 rail is required for P5vs0 to work. I do not have P5vs3 either. Any guidance on finding out what is going on is appreciated. thanks!


One other interesting thing: I check P5vs3 in continuity mode and everything looks good, but when plugging in DC power the impedance drops down to around 18 ohms (sill 0v)
I'm checking the line now for some mosfets that may have opened to a shorted line or something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
Ooops, do NOT measure resistance to ground on a powered board, on any point!!!

Exact voltage at F7040?
Do you get steady 3.3V at L7260 and 0.9V at L7750??
Touch <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground and look if L7220 pulses atleast?
If not, check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> pulse any.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> should be high always, as RTC signals too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7760</RESISTOR> is missing. I am not sure if that is normal. On the schematic it doesn't say nostuff. I think this is what connects the s5 to the s3 rail. I am getting s5 LDO, just no s3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
f7040 is 8.37
L7260  gives me 0v
L7750 gives me nothing

I am not sure how to check the rest for pulses and what not

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
no pulse at L7220 when using power on pads. 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> gives me a steady .19v no matter what. with the pwr pads. 
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is not pulsing either.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
"L7750 gives me nothing"
Solve that first, if not shorted...

Also check if L6995 shows more than 30K (200k scale), as normal for MCP platform.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
Ok, L7750 is not shorted to ground, but the resistance is around 1k. 
L6995 is showing around 6.6k

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: I'm getting no P3v3S5, which is needed for pv095. The enable pin (<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>) is fine, yet I am getting 0 volts out of the chip. could be a dead chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: SLG4AP012 is the chip that I think needs replacing.. now if I could just find a replacement.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: 6.6Kohms on PP3v42 is too low. MCP is dead this is done tbh.

threads.message: PP3v42 is actually 60k ohms. I must have measured something else.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
"L7260 gives me 0v"
Sorry, I forgot about this.

"what is MCP?"
Try to find a coincidence in the first schematic page.
Or look directly at schematic block.

Any short/low value at L7220/60?
Post <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> voltages first.

threads.message:
L7220 20k and rising
L7260 30k and rising

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
So, from what I can gather, pin 4 is <SIGNAL>EN_L</SIGNAL>, which I think means enable low. This maybe means there should be voltage on this pin too to enable the circuit,  but when I look upstream from there, there are two transistors that seem to come from the cpu to send a signal to it. There could be something wrong with one of the transistors or something else, but it seems likely to me at this point to be a dead mcp. 
The weird part to me, is that on the schematic the <SIGNAL>EN_L</SIGNAL> pin seems to be only related to wlan, which shouldn’t be needed to achieve an S5 state. 

I couldnt find find a data sheet on the chip to tell what that pin did, but I think the pin 4 is preventing it from turning on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7840</CHIP> is OK.
Pay atention to the circle from pin4; that means inverted output (as _L specifies low level)!

Now post some voltages at <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>; pins 23, 29, 22, 4, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: It may be 0v because of <RESISTOR>R7864</RESISTOR> missing on the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> line. this is needed to allow the voltage through the transistor I think

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: from all I can tell, the signal coming from the MCP or SMC is not telling the transistor to turn on, so It must be a dead MCP

threads.message: Voltage on the RTC crystal? You are shorting the power pads to try and turn it on? Does the light turn orange when battery connected?

threads.message:
1. The voltage on y2810 is 1.7 on the top and 1.5 on the bottom
2. I do short the pads to turn it on, but  I get the same voltages regardless.
3. The light turns green, but does not turn orange with battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> even present? PPBUS voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: 3v3 S5 is not present. PPbus 3v42g3h is present. so it's like it's getting to <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> and not coming out. <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is present but <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is not showing DC voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is present but <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is not showing DC voltage."
"Pay atention to the circle from pin4; that means inverted output (as _L specifies low level)!"
Unfortunatelly you don't pay such atention; <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is correct...

"3v3 S5 is not present."
"21 3.5v"
So <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is enabled.
Change <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> if you don't find any short around.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message: Ok, I think it makes sense now. Inverted means it's basically 0 and that makes it in an ON state. I'll double check 7201. it seems to be working, but it could be a sensitive chip if the outputs were shorted momentarily.

threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> greenlight, but no fanspin
threads.message:
""3v3 S5 is not present."
"21 3.5v"
So <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is enabled.
Change [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/d2-<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>.html"]<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>[/URL] if you don't find any short around."
